messages.text:
Hi, I'm Alexander, an astrophysics PhD student in Moscow. I use Julia in my everyday work starting from its first 1.0 release. It basically replaced Python for me pretty fast, except for code we write together with colleagues - almost no one around uses Julia...
If anyone curious :slightly_smiling_face:, I mostly study quasars using radio telescopes as the main workhorse. Other instruments such as neutrino telescopes come up as well from time to time (like now).

messages.text: Hello, I'm a biologist (postdoc) at Massachusetts General Hospital. I've been using Julia for about a year on my computational project analyzing superresolution microscopy data after I realized how slow MATLAB was (parsing strings when passing arguments was taking up so much processing power!). I developed an ANOVA package (SimpleANOVA.jl), and I've also got a PR pending for Julia to provide for an n-dimensional array concatenation syntax.

elements.text: Hello, I'm a biologist (postdoc) at Massachusetts General Hospital. I've been using Julia for about a year on my computational project analyzing superresolution microscopy data after I realized how slow MATLAB was (parsing strings when passing arguments was taking up so much processing power!). I developed an ANOVA package (SimpleANOVA.jl), and I've also got a PR pending for Julia to provide for an n-dimensional array concatenation syntax.

Thanks <@U69BL50BF> sir

messages.text: Hello all! I was just brought on to CIRES/NOAA’s Global Systems Laboratory to work on evaluating Julia in comparison to the existing Fortran and C++ code currently used to run their weather models. I’m new to Julia (and scientific computing), so I’m happy this group is in existence, and hope to get involved/ask questions in due time! :wave:

messages.text: Hey everyone, I’m Brady! I’m a front end developer with a background in physics and math, and I’m interested in helping people (including myself) build intuition for physics and math concepts using accessible, interactive visuals. I finally decided to learn Julia after getting fed up with JavaScript while working on an ODE solver, and realizing that Julia solves most of the problems I ran up against. My hope is to eventually use Julia as a back end for accessible, animated learning apps in the browser.

elements.text: Hey everyone, I’m Brady! I’m a front end developer with a background in physics and math, and I’m interested in helping people (including myself) build intuition for physics and math concepts using accessible, interactive visuals. I finally decided to learn Julia after getting fed up with JavaScript while working on an ODE solver, and realizing that Julia solves most of the problems I ran up against. My hope is to eventually use Julia as a back end for accessible, animated learning apps in the browser.

messages.text: Hello everyone, I'm a curious coder who is forever in love with mathematics and I've found my way to Julia. I have forked the repo on GitHub and have watched all the open training <https://julialang.org/learning/>. Any advice to help get started is valued!

messages.text: Hi everyone! I'm Alvaro, currently a quantitative researcher in finance with a background in math and economics. Been using Julia for some projects lately and wrote a blog post on Vox EU about comparing it to the other main econ programming languages, <https://voxeu.org/article/which-programming-language-best-economic-research|you can find it here>. Excited to be a part of this community.

attachments.title: Which programming language is best for economic research?
attachments.text: The most widely used programming languages for economic research are Julia, Matlab, Python and R. This column uses three criteria to compare the languages: the power of available libraries, the speed
attachments.fallback: Which programming language is best for economic research?

you can find it here
. Excited to be a part of this community.

I've been looking into contributing for open sourced projects and would love to contribute to this community. I've sound background in Numerical Methods, Chemical Engg.(Majoring), Linear algebra and DEs.
Any suggested channels aligning with my interests? Thanks in advance :)

messages.text: Hi! I'm Rishabh, a final year Integrated Master's student of the Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, majoring in Math & Computing. My interests align in Computational and Bayesian Statistics, primarily in analysing and developing MCMC techniques, but not restricted to it. I used Julia as change of pace for doing my assignments for Non Linear Programming and I would like to contribute to any project aligned towards statistical computing. Maybe Turing.jl would be a good place to start? (Also, what kinds of projects are of current interests in the Julia community? I would like to work on the recent advances in coupling based MCMC techniques <https://arxiv.org/abs/1708.03625>)

attachments.title: Unbiased Markov chain Monte Carlo with couplings
attachments.text: Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods provide consistent of integrals as the number of iterations goes to infinity. MCMC estimators are generally biased after any fixed number of iterations. We...
attachments.fallback: arXiv.org: Unbiased Markov chain Monte Carlo with couplings

messages.text: Hi all! I'm a cinematographer and digital imaging technician <http://brettharrison.co|brettharrison.co>. I'm interested in new ways to apply computer science to image formation, using PDEs from the world of neuroscience and vision science (for example <http://ip4ec.upf.edu|ip4ec.upf.edu>) and incorporate dynamics. I've worked a bit with Matlab and C++ in the past to experiment with existing code, and I'm excited to learn Julia in order to experiment with making my own code. I'm very excited to join this community!

messages.text:
Hello everyone,
I graduated with a master's in simulation sciences from RWTH Aachen (Germany). A close friend of mine who is an ardent supporter of Julia since its initial release seeded the thought of porting my assignment codes from Python and C++ to Julia. I must have heeded to his advice earlier, but I have much more time now to explore and learn such a powerful language while applying for PhD positions. Dr. Herriman's lecture series was so much fun and got me started into exploring more into the documentation. Hope I can add more value to this language through opensource projects in the near future.
To fruitful conversations!

messages.text: Hi everyone! I am Manas Gupta and am an undergrad and have been fascinated by machines and programs that have the ability to make smart decisions, since I was a child. I find Neural Networks and Reinforcement Learning and math very interesting especially Linear algebra, Probability, Differential equations, Multivariable calculus. Oh and I love physics as well. I would love to get my hands dirty while trying out crazy new ideas that pop up in the AI community.  Also thinking about applying to gsoc to have a memorable summer this year and get a good experience with open source. Really looking forward to get to know everyone, contribute to the community and learn new things along with you all. :simple_smile:

messages.text: Hellohello. I've been a bit of a Julia lurker and dabbler, but recently decided to take it seriously. I'm broadly interested in stochastic processes, dynamical systems and machine learning. Especially the intersection of these, with applications to systems biology. I've really enjoyed my first dabbles with the SciML ecosystem. I'm also a wannabe Lisper, and I hear Julia's good for scratching that kind of itch.

messages.text: Hello everyone. I’m Eduardo Souza, a postdoc from the Australian National University. I’m more on the PL developer side rather than the user side, to be honest. I will be looking into Julia’s GC, trying to understand how it works wrt LLVM, and my long-term goal is to see if I can plug in the MMTk memory toolkit (<https://www.mmtk.io>), exploring Julia as a case study for using LLVM and MMTk together to implement managed languages. I’d appreciate any pointers from the devs, or just people I could get in touch if I end up getting stuck. Thanks in advance!

messages.text:
Hello everyone!

I’m Nathan, I’m a PhD student studying crowdsourcing/hybrid intelligence/philosophy of statistics at the Institute for Data Science & Artificial Intelligence at the University of Manchester. I’m a fairly proficient R user but have been slowly falling in love with Julia during lockdown!

I’m looking to move more of my research workflow over to Julia and eventually some of my teaching work too.
I’m particularly interested in using Julia as a GIS and learning how to develop packages for applications that don’t currently exist in Julia (such as a package for structural equation modelling, equivalent to what lavaan offers in R, and a package for multiverse/specification curve analyses).

elements.text:
Hello everyone!

I’m Nathan, I’m a PhD student studying crowdsourcing/hybrid intelligence/philosophy of statistics at the Institute for Data Science & Artificial Intelligence at the University of Manchester. I’m a fairly proficient R user but have been slowly falling in love with Julia during lockdown!

I’m looking to move more of my research workflow over to Julia and eventually some of my teaching work too.
I’m particularly interested in using Julia as a GIS and learning how to develop packages for applications that don’t currently exist in Julia (such as a package for structural equation modelling, equivalent to what lavaan offers in R, and a package for multiverse/specification curve analyses).

messages.text:
Hello everyone,
I'm Dodd (he/him), a postdoc working on a mix of topics in nonlinear optics, integrated photonics and Raman spectroscopy in the EECS dept. at MIT. I've been coming up to speed on Julia for the past several months and developing code for PDE-constrained optimization ("inverse design") of waveguides for short laser pulses. Migrating from using python to control compiled PDE solver libraries has been surprisingly approachable thanks to all of the great ongoing work in the Julia community and is already proving useful for my research. I am excited to join and hopefully contribute to the ecosystem.
I am currently focused on automatic differentiation applied to eigenmode solutions of parameterized PDEs (just the Helmholtz equation for now), Other relevant buzzwords include "adjoint method" and "matrix-free"/"implicit" operators. Please feel free to reach out if you have overlapping interests and would like to chat. I look forward to learning from/with you all.

elements.text:

I've been coming up to speed on Julia for the past several months and developing code for PDE-constrained optimization ("inverse design") of waveguides for short laser pulses. Migrating from using python to control compiled PDE solver libraries has been surprisingly approachable thanks to all of the great ongoing work in the Julia community and is already proving useful for my research. I am excited to join and hopefully contribute to the ecosystem.
I am currently focused on automatic differentiation applied to eigenmode solutions of parameterized PDEs (just the Helmholtz equation for now), Other relevant buzzwords include "adjoint method" and "matrix-free"/"implicit" operators. messages.text:
Hello,
I am an engineer doing sensor characterization and calibrations for a manufacturing company in Canada.
I started using Julia in 2017 to avoid writing complex wrappers in python. Had some fights with management over the years over it's use, and it looks like 2021 is the year where it's usage is finally accepted by management.
